entities.description: Indicates whether data has been statistically imputed.
Types of substances for which data can be statistically imputed, such as tobacco products, pain relievers, tranquilizers, stimulants, and sedatives.
Levels of imputation for recency of substance use, with varying degrees of edited recency from lifetime use to specific recency values.
Ensures that imputed values are consistent with preexisting, nonmissing values.
The process of using statistical methods to estimate missing data points.
Existing data points that are not missing and are used to maintain consistency during imputation.
A type of statistical analysis that involves multiple variables.
Different sections of the survey that contain questions related to specific topics, such as cocaine use or special drugs.
A variable that measures the time since the most recent use of a substance.
Methods and practices for handling inconsistencies that arise from imputation.
Variables that have been revised based on imputation processes.
A specific section of the questionnaire focused on the use of special drugs.

relationships.description: Relates the survey to the indicator for whether data has been statistically imputed.
Identifies the substances for which data can be imputed, such as tobacco products and various prescription drugs.
Specifies the level of imputation for the substance use data.
Ensures that imputed values remain consistent with existing, non-missing values.
Requires that the process of statistical imputation maintains consistency with existing data.
Involves the use of imputation-revised variables in multivariate statistical analysis.
Questionnaire sections contain questions that determine the recency of substance use.
Methods for resolving inconsistencies in imputation-revised variables.
Recency variables are components of different sections of the questionnaire.
Special drugs section is part of the overall questionnaire.
